Dear Stephanie Rae Sears:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Compliance with the child protection law
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12214
Section • (1) An agency shall comply with the child protection law,
Description 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster care agency was made aware of injuries to a foster child
with unknown causes and failed to report this for almost 2 weeks.
Foster care never inquired with the caregiver about the cause of
the injuries or requested a medical exam.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant was interviewed by phone on 5/17/2024 at which
time Complainant reiterated the concerns noted in the complaint.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via video conferencing on
5/23/2024. She reported receiving an email Friday, 4/26/2024
from a person supervising Youth A’s parental visitation with
photos of injuries on Youth A’s arms and face. Foster Care
Worker stated she did not see the email until the following
Monday, 4/29/2024 at which time she forwarded the email and
photos to Foster Care Supervisor. Foster Care Worker reported
meeting with Foster Care Supervisor the same day for supervision
during which Foster Care Supervisor told Foster Care Worker she
was going to consult with her colleagues about the photos and
how to proceed. Foster Care Worker didn’t hear anything further
until she met with Foster Care Supervisor the following week.
During that meeting Foster Care Supervisor asked Foster Care
Worker if she had followed up with Caregiver to find out if she
knew the cause of the injuries as she told her to do. Foster Care
Worker had not done so and did not recall Foster Care Supervisor
telling her to. At that time, Foster Care Supervisor advised Foster
Care Worker to report the injuries to MDHHS. Foster Care Worker
acknowledged that she should have reported the injuries as soon
as she saw the photos instead of waiting on her supervisor to
consult with colleagues.
2

Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via video conferencing
on 5/23/2024. She reported she reviewed the email forwarded by
Foster Care Worker and the photos of the injuries on Youth A on
4/29/2024. She stated she was the worker on the case previously
and she did not have any concerns with Caregiver. She stated
Youth A has had hand, foot and mouth disease a couple of times
and has had bad bug bites, so the photos didn’t alarm her. She
stated she had supervision with Foster Care Worker on 5/1/2024
at which time Foster Care Worker asked if she had seen the
photos of Youth A. They looked at the photos together and Foster
Care Supervisor told Foster Care Worker she was going to get a
second opinion on the photos and would follow up with her after.
Foster Care Supervisor stated it crossed her mind to have Foster
Care Worker report the injuries to MDHHS, but she never said it
out loud. Foster Care Supervisor stated she consulted with a co-
worker as well as a MDHHS staff member about the photos. She
stated the coworker advised her to ask Caregiver if she knew
anything about the marks. MDHHS worker told her to “maybe call
it in.” Foster Care Worker reached out to Foster Care Supervisor
on 5/7/2024 asking if she had gotten the second opinion at which
time Foster Care Supervisor asked Foster Care Worker if she had
followed up with the Caregiver. Foster Care Worker had not, so
Foster Care Supervisor advised her to report the injuries to
MDHHS which she did on 5/8/2024, a week and a half after the
photos were initially reviewed. Foster Care Supervisor stated she
made a “rookie mistake” and misguided Foster Care Worker by
telling her to wait to report the injuries. Foster Care Supervisor
stated the agency policy is to not investigate such concerns,
rather to report the concerns to MDHHS. Foster Care Supervisor
stated Caregiver has been doing well up to this point, so she
decided to check with her before reporting the injuries.
MDHHS Worker was interviewed by phone on 5/17/2024 and
5/24/2024. MDHHS Worker stated a medical examination was
completed on Youth A and pictures of the injuries were shown to
the physician; however, due to there being a delay and the injuries
having been mostly healed, the cause of injury could not be
determined. She reported she spoke with Foster Care Supervisor
who apologized for not reporting the injuries of Youth A timely.
MDHHS Worker stated no one has been able to provide an
explanation for the injuries. She reported Youth A was removed
from Caregiver’s home on 5/23/2024 in part due to the
unexplained injuries which were suspicious in nature.
Director of Foster Care was interviewed by video conferencing
on 6/4/2024. She reported not hearing about the marks on Youth
3

A until after MDHHS Worker began an investigation. Director of
Foster Care stated she has since been told by Foster Care
Supervisor that she and Foster Care Worker were made aware of
the marks by the designee supervising Youth A’s parenting time
after which Foster Care Worker and Foster Care Supervisor tried
to determine the cause of the marks. Director of Foster Care
reported there are times youth have marks that wouldn’t create
concern such as injuries previously reported by caregivers that
occurred during play, or marks such as mosquito bites; however, a
youth arriving to a visit with unexplained marks that were not
identifiable in nature would be reason to report the marks.
Senior Director of Child Welfare Programs was interviewed by
video conferencing on 6/4/2024. She reported being aware of the
concerns related to the delay in reporting the marks on Youth A.
She stated the guidance given by Foster Care Supervisor to
Foster Care Worker to try to determine the cause of the marks
before reporting the marks is not the guidance that should have
been given to Foster Care Worker.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
-Email dated 4/26/2024 from the individual supervising Youth A’s
parenting time documenting she attached photos of what she
stated appeared to be “healing burn marks” on Youth A’s face and
arm.
-Five photos of round, healing injuries on Youth A’s arm and
jawline.
-Incident report completed by Foster Care Worker on 4/29/2024
documenting the marks on Youth A signed by Foster Care Worker
and Foster Care Supervisor.
-Supervision notes dated 5/6/2024 documenting supervision was
held to discuss the case.
-Agency mandated Reporting Policy which indicates all foster care
positions are considered mandated reporters and must
immediately make a report of suspected child abuse or neglect.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as Foster Care Worker
and Foster Care Supervisor did not comply with child protection
law by failing to report injuries observed on Youth A for nearly two
weeks.
Conclusion Violation Established

Rule Code Placement
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404
Section • (4) An agency shall consider all the following factors in
Description selecting an appropriate placement for a child:
• (b) The physical, emotional, and educational needs
of the child.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Foster care was aware that the foster child has been living in a
placement found to be deplorable and has failed to report or
document the conditions.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant was interviewed by phone on 5/17/2024 at which
time Complainant reiterated the concerns noted in the complaint.
MDHHS Worker was interviewed by phone on 5/17/2024 and
5/24/2024. MDHHS Worker reported she observed Caregiver’s
home on 5/8/2024 at which time there was animal feces and urine
everywhere except in the children’s bedrooms. MDHHS Worker
stated Foster Care Worker told her she has never seen the home
in the condition MDHHS Worker saw the home after which
MDHHS Worker informed Foster Care Worker she should make
an unannounced visit to the home. MDHHS Worker stated
Caregiver had people help her clean up her home prior to Foster
Care Worker’s next visit, which was scheduled, after which
Caregiver sent photos of the home to MDHHS Worker. Foster
Care Worker reported to MDHHS Worker that the concerns with
the home had been rectified. MDHHS Worker stated she visited
the home again unannounced on 5/23/2024 at which time the
home was in the same if not worse condition as it was on the 8th.
She stated there was again filth and animal feces throughout the
home. She stated the basement of the home was in such poor
condition MDHHS worker did not even go down the stairs and
took pictures from where she stood. She stated the upstairs of the
home was deplorable and there was a cat litter box piled with
animal waste. MDHHS Worker reported Youth A was removed
from Caregiver A’s home due to imminent risk of harm to the
youth based in part on the conditions of the home.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via video conferencing on
5/23/2024. She reported Caregiver’s home is “not the cleanest”
but she has never had any issues or concerns with safety. She
stated she has never seen feces or urine in the home and has
5

never seen it as unclean as the photos taken by MDHHS Worker.
She stated the home is cluttered, but the floors are cleared. Foster
Care Worker stated she completed a visit to Caregiver’s home on
4/25/2024 at which time the home was in the condition she
typically sees the home. She reported she received the photos
from MDHHS Worker from her 5/8/2024 visit. Foster Care Worker
visited the home the following day at which time there was no
animal feces or urine, and the home was significantly cleaned up.
Caregiver took pictures of the home that day which she sent to
Foster Care Worker and MDHHS Worker. Foster Care Worker
stated she visited the home again on 5/22/2024 and the home
was in the same condition it was in during her last visit. She stated
that visit was also scheduled. Foster Care Worker stated
Caregiver told her she was still picking up and that the basement
had flooded. Foster Care Worker stated she did not see the
basement and did not go upstairs as Caregiver told her it was too
messy for her to go up there. Foster Care Worker stated there are
no bedrooms in the basement or upstairs. Foster Care Worker
reiterated she feels the home is acceptable and safe.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via video conferencing
on 5/23/2024. She reported she was the worker on the case from
April 2022 until Foster Care Worker took over in September 2023.
She stated Caregiver has moved a few times and there have
never been safety concerns with any of her homes. She reported
the kitchen has never been “the cleanest” and there are typically
dishes stacked up as if she washed them once a week. She sated
the emergency exits, window screens, locks, and baby gates have
all been clear and intact. She stated the homes have all been
appropriately baby proofed. She stated when she was the pictures
taken by MDHHS Worker she was very shocked as she has never
seen the home in that condition and has never seen feces or urine
in the home. Foster Care Supervisor reported Caregiver’s current
home is more than an hour away from the agency, so it isn’t
reasonable to make unannounced visits. She stated she visited
the home along with Foster Care Worker earlier this year and
there were no safety concerns at that time. She stated the floors
were all clear except for toys, which were corralled within a
specific area by baby gates.
Director of Foster Care was interviewed by video conferencing
on 6/4/2024. She reported not hearing about concerns with the
cleanliness of Caregiver’s home until the MDHHS Worker began
an investigation. She reported Foster Care Worker developed a
safety plan with Caregiver to rectify the cleanliness concerns.
Director of Foster Care stated she believed Caregiver was able to
6

clean the home for Foster Care Worker’s visits but was not able to
maintain that level of cleanliness between visits. She stated she
was unaware the worker had neither seen the upstairs nor the
basement of the home.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
-Ten photos of Caregiver’s home taken by MDHHS Worker on
5/8/2024 showing the home in the condition MDHHS Worker
described during her interview.
-Six photos of Caregiver’s home taken by Caregiver on 5/9/2024
showing the home in the condition Foster Care Worker described
during her interview.
-Eighteen photos of Caregiver’s home taken by MDHHS Worker
on 5/23/2024 showing the home in the condition MDHHS Worker
described during her interview.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as the Foster Care
Worker and Foster Care Supervisor did not ensure the safety and
appropriateness of the home by failing to view the upstairs or
basement, which were unsanitary and unsafe. Additionally, after
MDHHS Worker observed the home in deplorable condition,
Foster Care Worker scheduled an announced visit to the home
and determined the concerns were rectified; however, the home
was again observed in deplorable conditions within two weeks.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
